Bob Wallace.Action: Acknowledges and thanks the audience, shows respect to General Waverly by highlighting his contributions, and tries to cover the General's embarrassment by offering help.
Removes his beard and buttons his shirt hurriedly when reprimanded, showing respect for authority but also some casualness.
Holds up his hand for silence to address the group confidently after the performance.
Removes his beard and speaks clearly about the change in command, showing awareness and leadership.
Automatically stiffens and responds appropriately to General Waverly's bellowed command, showing discipline and alertness.
Hastily buttons his shirt when reprimanded for being out of uniform, showing quick compliance but also a minor oversight.
Covers General Waverly's embarrassment smoothly by offering to help him, demonstrating social competence and tact.
Sings WHITE CHRISTMAS with fellow soldiers in a trench during war, sharing a moment of hope and camaraderie.
Eyes Phil with a hostile look after being pulled down to safety, but continues singing together.
Gives the downbeat to start the song, helping General Waverly out of embarrassment.
Begins singing White Christmas at the prearranged signal despite dangerous circumstances.
Responds immediately to enemy barrage by being pulled down by Phil, showing quick physical reaction to danger.
Shows mild frustration with Phil's behavior but continues to perform without disruption.
Gives the cast a week off with pay for Christmas, despite potential financial loss for their manager.
Acknowledges they will have to work hard while others rest, showing consideration and responsibility.
Decides to go to New York for four days and nights of rehearsals despite the inconvenience, showing dedication and willingness to work hard.
Responds calmly and pragmatically to the manager's complaint about financial loss, indicating steady decision-making under pressure.
Plans the group's activities sensibly by suggesting dinner while waiting for the train, demonstrating practical and confident planning.
Takes Phil by the arm and pulls him away from Rita to have dinner, using playful and friendly language ('Come on, Romeo, dinner!','Lamb chops, lamb chops!')
Takes charge by pulling Phil away from Rita and insists on going to dinner despite Phil's reluctance.
Focuses on the task at hand (dinner) rather than distractions (does not look at the girls at the bar).
Ignores social distractions and stay focused on priorities.
Jokingly admonishes Phil to 'lay off the female sex' and reminds him of their agreement not to chase new tidbits.
Uses a playful nickname 'Rover' for Phil, showing friendly teasing.
Watches Phil bring over the sick girl with disgust, showing lack of empathy in contrast to Phil's tenderness.
Politely interacts with Novello and allows the girls to be seated, engaging respectfully with others.
Declines dessert politely and deflects conversation about it, indicating self-control and awareness of circumstances.
Responds to Novello's comment about booking by confidently suggesting calling their agent and noting limited availability.
Watches Phil’s overly emotional behavior with disgust, showing emotional intelligence and discernment.
Politely greets Judy and Betty and thanks them sincerely for liking the show.
Shows little to no emotional reaction when Judy mentions she is from Canton, Ohio.
Engages in friendly banter by asking Judy questions to verify details, then compliments Phil with a firm handshake showing respect and warmth.
Acknowledges and admires Phil's talent including 'the little lies all around the big one,' suggesting appreciation without sarcasm or mockery.
Encourages Phil not to belittle himself and gives him credit.
Lightheartedly teases Judy's previous name but in a friendly manner.
Takes Betty's arm and suggests they follow and watch over the couple to support them.
Engages in playful banter about watching over Phil and Judy's relationship, showing care.
Encourages Phil by acknowledging his effort and telling him not to belittle himself.
Takes initiative by organizing monitoring of Phil and Judy to keep them dancing, showing strategic thinking and confidence.
Uses humor and insight regarding Phil and Judy’s relationship dynamics, indicating social intelligence and awareness.
Flats Judy sincerely and encourages friendly interaction by playful teasing with Phil (e.g., 'bubble lover,' train whistle imitation).
Does not sit with the group, possibly indicating slight detachment or formality.
Keeps track of the train schedule and insists they leave on time despite others' reluctance.
Pulls Phil away to keep moving toward catching the train on time, showing leadership and decisiveness.
Does not sit down like others, indicating alertness and readiness to act.
Offers help to the girls despite tense situation.
Tells others not to get panicky, attempting to keep calm.
Questions the reason for arrest with genuine curiosity, showing concern.
Looks suspiciously at Phil, showing distrust temporarily.
Shows awareness that the old burned rug routine is outdated and suggests they need to do something new.
Admits only having a 'glimmer' of a new idea and needing to stir it around a little.
Bows off after the performance and hurries to the dressing room without noticing the Sheriff behind them.
Greets old friends warmly with enthusiastic physical gestures and affectionate teasing.
Reminisces about past events including a deceased friend with respect and a touch of humor.
Engages warmly and confidently with the Sheriff, showing familiarity and ease in social interaction.
Asks questions and remembers past events carefully, showing good recall and conversational intelligence.
Does not take any decisive or skill-based action in the scene, mostly reminiscing and socializing.
Thanks the Sheriff politely before leaving in the police car.
Checks his watch and insists they must get their bags and be at the station in ten minutes, showing awareness of time constraints and urgency.
Thanks the Sheriff as he leaves through the window, showing polite and confident interaction with authority.
Expresses willingness to be together on the train to New York, shows light teasing and attention to friends' wishes, though declines trip to Vermont for practical reasons.
Coordinates with the group to escape together and ensures they stay united until New York.
Balances social ask with practical constraints by refusing to extend the trip despite friends' wishes due to obligations in New York.
Dismisses the idea of a snowy Christmas lightly, showing some pragmatic realism.
Jokes protectively about smashing flexible flyer if Phil tries to take Betty's sister for a sleigh ride.
Acknowledges Phil's compliment with a practical remark about needing to sleep.
Calmly reassures others and confidently confirms plans with 'It's all set.'
Displays protective attitude by threatening to smash the flexible flyer if a friend tries to take Betty's sister for a sleigh ride.
Suggests getting some sleep to be ready for the night, showing practical foresight.
Confidently directs the bus driver by saying, 'Driver, your sleigh and reindeer,' showing quick wit and ease in uncertain surroundings.
Politely interacts with Martha and General Waverly, showing respect and friendliness.
Decides not to stay at the inn after learning about the poor conditions.
Engages politely with Martha, asks relevant questions about accommodations and rates, and quickly adapts when realizing the situation is not as expected.
Starts to leave but stops abruptly and shows proper respect when recognizing General Waverly, demonstrating awareness and good social judgment.
Shows some initial bewilderment and uncertainty when greeted by General Waverly, indicating a momentary lapse in confidence or clarity.
Introduces himself confidently and smoothly in a social/business situation.
Stiffens automatically at mention of K.P., showing military discipline and readiness.
Responds with a witty but controlled comment about the Draft Board.
Responds to Judy's wish to help by saying 'Maybe there is' and showing willingness to find a solution.
Makes light, humorous remarks about Waverly (We ate and then he ate. We slept, and then he slept.) showing friendly tolerance.
Suggests there might be a way to help the struggling business, showing initiative and problem-solving mindset.
Engages in light banter about Waverly's stubbornness, demonstrating awareness but not taking direct action yet.
Calmly manages costly arrangements to help the troupe, showing care and commitment despite financial burden.
Takes responsibility for money matters to protect others (Phil) from stress, showing prudence and kindness.
Brings the whole show to rehearse despite potential concerns for Gramp's pride and situation.
Insists they are not doing the show for Gramp to avoid his pride issues but actually to rehearse, showing practicality over sentiment.
Takes initiative to bring the whole show to rehearse at the Columbia Inn, demonstrating planning and logistical skill.
Explains contract obligations confidently and clearly, showing awareness of legal and professional responsibilities.
Assertively clarifies intentions about motivations (not doing it for Gramp), showing confidence and clear communication.
Tries to secure rehearsal space with little money, showing consideration and practicality.
Makes lighthearted jokes about receiving gratitude from Susan, showing friendly and self-deprecating humor.
Responds sincerely to Betty’s compliment, acknowledging the kindness without arrogance.
Negotiates use of the hall for rehearsal, offering to pay something despite tight resources.
Uses humor and self-deprecation after Susan's emotional reaction, showing social ease and confidence.
Admits surprise at Betty's sincere praise, showing some humility and openness to feedback.
Suggests using an empty room for rehearsing to give the troupe a chance to practice and have an audience, showing consideration and initiative.
Engages respectfully and patiently with Waverly, explaining show business to someone unfamiliar without condescension.
Identifies and utilizes an empty space as an ideal location for rehearsing, demonstrating practical problem-solving and situational awareness.
Explains the importance of having an audience to try out new material, showing understanding of performance dynamics and strategy.
Confidently asserts that word of their performance will spread naturally, indicating confidence in social influence and publicity.
Engages collaboratively and supports Phil’s plans, demonstrating teamwork and reliable partnership.
Takes Martha by the arm and seats her comfortably as an audience of one to listen to a song he wrote, wanting her sincere opinion.
Performs a song solely for Martha to show consideration and respect.
Takes initiative to introduce new music by showing it to Phil and arranging a private performance with Martha, demonstrating leadership and confidence.
Demonstrates musical skill by performing a new song solo and generating emotional responses from the audience.
Exchanges a quick, understanding glance with Phil demonstrating awareness and teamwork.
Continues working late into the night fingering piano keys and writing music notes, showing dedication and skill.
Takes Betty in his arms when she quietly joins him outside, showing tenderness and comfort.
Speaks to Betty gently and playfully about sleep-walking, indicating friendly concern and lightheartedness.
Sits calmly outside, putting out his pipe and reflecting quietly, showing self-control and thoughtfulness.
Gives clear, helpful information about the location of tuna fish in the fridge to Betty, indicating awareness and attention to detail.
Offers to make Betty food and warm milk to help her insomnia; tries to engage her with playful conversation about dreams and food.
Does not recognize Betty's deeper emotional signals and is oblivious to her yearning and true feelings.
Prepares warm milk and sings a soothing song to Betty, then thoughtfully puts a pillow behind her head before quietly leaving so she can rest.
Attempts to maintain show order and address concerns tactfully, sensing the awkwardness about Sylvia's condition.
Examines the music sheet with Betty, showing engagement and focus on the task at hand.
Observes social interactions quietly, smiling at Betty's protective behavior but does not intervene.
Offers Betty reassuring words about Phil, attempting to comfort her in a difficult moment.
Comforts Betty by offering a calm, confident perspective on Phil's character, showing emotional intelligence and social awareness.
Enters quietly and notices emotional shifts around him, suggesting good situational awareness and sensitivity.
Looks searchingly at Betty, puzzled about her story, indicating concern and attentiveness.
Does not address or accuse Betty directly despite his doubts, showing restraint and tolerance.
Looks searchingly at Betty, puzzled by her story, indicating careful observation and critical thinking.
Responds confidently and humorously when discussing his knowledge of women, showing quick wit and self-assuredness.
Appears puzzled and slow to recognize his own feelings toward Betty, showing a lack of self-awareness.
Admits he is single and refuses to admit true feelings about Betty going away, showing some reservation and defensiveness.
Watches Phil and Judy dancing with a slightly belligerent tone and intense staring at Phil, indicating possible resentment and lack of open friendliness.
Makes a blunt, somewhat harsh comment about Phil's appearance but says 'nothing personal'.
Tries to help Waverly understand the weather and responds positively to his news about rejoining the Army.
Respectfully keeps Waverly's confidence about going back to the Army and does not reveal it to others.
Accurately observes weather conditions and attempts to reason about the forecast.
Forgets the letter initially but then remembers and produces it for Waverly.
Engages respectfully and shows understanding in conversation with Waverly, maintaining composure.

Responds respectfully to Waverly despite being unhappy and trapped.
Makes a casual, teasing remark to Phil about his soulful eyes.

Easily annoyed and somewhat sharp with Phil when teased.
Maintains calm and respectful demeanor despite being trapped and unhappy; responds politely to Waverly's authority.
Reflects quietly and thoughtfully after interaction with Waverly, showing self-awareness.
Packs suitcase methodically with help from Phil, indicating readiness and organization.
Shoves a sentimental item hastily into his bag, suggesting possible avoidance or emotional discomfort.
Responds easily annoyed to Phil’s teasing about girls, revealing a brief lapse in emotional control.
Compliments Betty's singing to encourage her.
Thanks Betty sincerely for the knitted sock.
Engages in playful, somewhat flirtatious banter with Betty, showing friendly warmth and openness.
Carefully reveals personal insecurity about limited time left for romance.
Initiates a plan to boost morale by organizing a surprise reunion for their old commander.
Shares a carefully considered idea with a friend to help others feel appreciated and uplifted.

Carefully explains the situation to Ed and uses strategic communication to rally support.

Comforts the women who begin to cry, tries to maintain composure and encouragement.

Asks about the progress and tries to keep morale up when others are emotional, looks to others for support, stays composed despite emotional situation.

Steps back quickly to avoid embarrassing the lovers he sees, showing social awareness and control.
